title: Aging With HIV

content: I’m not old, but I’m aging – with HIV. I’ve lived with it for 25 years. It’s hard to imagine myself as a long term survivor, but here I am. And thanks to modern medicine, I’m not alone. In fact, the number of older people living with HIV is increasing.
ART (antiretroviral therapy) has progressed so much that people who live with HIV are now more concerned with comorbidities than death.

Chronic conditions seem to multiply from out of nowhere as you age. I remember when I had to start wearing glasses at 45, as degenerative conditions slowly became the norm. Along with HIV, I also live with COPD, adult ADHD, PTSD, and severe chronic depression.

I’ve also been experiencing cognitive impairment and severe memory loss. Not all of these conditions are derived from HIV, and they may or may not affect me more because of HIV. Many of them can’t be resolved. But they can’t be ignored because they could do me even more harm.

content: Aging demands that we make more trips to the doctor’s office for checkups and screenings. It’s important we keep these appointments and take them seriously to catch potential problems early. It’s important to have a good relationship with your doctors, keep them apprised of each other, and make sure they know about all your medical care so there’s no miscommunication, misunderstanding, or mistreatment.

Cognitive health is also something to pay attention to as you age with HIV. Cognitive decline happens to a lot of us as we age and, to some degree, it’s normal. But when you live with HIV, it can be more drastic.

There’s a term for it: HIV-associated neurocognitive disorder (HAND). It can affect your memory, motor skills, thinking, mood, and behavior. Advances in ART over the past two decades have significantly decreased the severity of HAND – but it affects 30% to 50% of people living with HIV. The most severe form of HAND is called HAD (HIV-associated dementia). This occurs in less than 5% of people with HIV who are on the right treatment plan. MND (mild neurocognitive disorder) is a more common form of HAND. It can affect your behavior, ability to make decisions, learning, concentration, attention, and memory.

content: Another challenge of aging with HIV is how medication management becomes more complex. That’s because you're more likely to develop other health conditions you need medications for, too. So there’s more risk of drug interactions and side effects. This is something your doctors and pharmacists try to stay on top of, but no one knows your body like you. So listen to it, and make sure your providers listen to you.

Medication adherence is important, and it may get more challenging with age. A medication routine is helpful. It may be as simple as a pillbox and alarms, or it may mean asking others for help. Listen to your doctor's recommendations, but find a routine you can stick to.

Social support and interaction are crucial as you age. Depression and other mental health issues become more of a concern. Loneliness is a major issue for older adults that negatively impacts your mental and physical well-being. It can lead to serious issues such as substance dependence and suicidal ideation.

content: But it’s not always easy to find socialization. Sometimes there are no support groups, social centers, or even family. Loneliness is a real struggle for many aging people, even more so when you live with HIV.

Aging isn’t fun, but when you live with HIV, you need to be extra aware and proactive about related issues. Isn’t it interesting that the public often thinks of HIV as a death sentence, yet those who actually live with it are more concerned about aging than death?
I’m not too happy about aging. But, then again, perhaps I shouldn’t be aging at all. It’s the incredible science behind modern HIV medications that’s credited for my survival. I’m grateful for it.
